according to the latest information, a bike stolen from the center of helsinki has been found on the espoo side, but the suspected bike thief has not been found. fortunately, this bike was not lost, but it eventually ends up back to its owner.

you can prepare for theft in advance by keeping the bike's identification information and taking photos of the bike. you should also get a decent lock for your bike. if your bike is stolen, you can file a criminal report in the police's electronic transaction service.

the police tried to tire out the bike thief with their intransigence, but so far the suspect has not been found. bicycle theft increases steadily as summer approaches, and spring is the peak season for theft.

the police had a small chase mission in the city center in the evening, where the police tried to catch up with a bike thief. in the early evening, the emergency center received a report about a suspected bike theft, and soon the patrols nearby noticed a person matching the description driving towards the railway station.

a police camera drone takes off every day and the operations are at the top in the world drones save money and time, as well as lives
police drones take to the air every day and the operations are world-leading drones save both time and money and save lives
the police have their own drone operations, but the police are also prepared for countermeasures, that is, possible threats brought by drones.

in addition to everyday police work, photography helicopters are also used in special operations, for example the national emergency unit in karhu. aerial photography can help, for example, with security inspections related to explosives.

the benefits brought by drones are versatile. in about half of the tasks performed with a photography helicopter, the helicopter is put into the air to search for a missing person, but they can also be used to do a lot more.
the police filming helicopter takes off every day and we are at the top of the world in operation. drones save money, time and save lives.

read the full story on identifying and investigating hate crimes: .

today, the police's electronic crime reporting system has its own classification for hate crimes, which helps to notice the cases in the early stages of the preliminary investigation. identifying hate crimes belongs to every police officer who records crime reports.(4)

the police have an obligation to find out whether it is a hate crime, if the reporting party believes that the suspected crime is motivated by hate. the helsinki police have their own investigation team, which is focused on identifying and prosecuting hate crimes.(3)

it's a hate crime if the suspect's act was influenced by the person concerned's race, skin color, ancestry, national or ethnic origin, religion or belief, sexual orientation, disability, etc. the motives for the crime in question are grounds for increasing the punishment.(2)

a hate crime can be any crime - it's the motive that countsthe motive is prejudice or hatred, e.g. towards the ethnic group represented by the victim. can also target the "mainstream population".the notifications have the most characteristics of harassment targeting ethnic or national background.(1)

according to the internal security report, the amount of crime has been decreasing in finland for the last years. background factors of crime for both perpetrators and victims include exclusion, substance use, personality traits, and disorders.
according to a report by , the increase in violent crime among minors between and is not related to a specific population group, region, phenomenon or event location:

in finland, street gangs do not control streets or residential areas. however, the individuals who belong to them have a wide influence on social media platforms, where they fuel the idealization and confrontation of the criminal lifestyle.

the first observations of the street gang phenomenon were made in may , when the cycle of violence between two different groups began. these serious crimes were effectively investigated, and in october , the helsinki police prevented violence between street gangs in kaivohuone.

a street gang is a group formed by several people with their own name and identity. gang members commit various crimes together and alone. the names of identified gangs often refer to streets or neighborhoods.
police commander lasse aapio emphasizes the importance of cooperation in fighting gang crime.violent crimes by minors, street gangs and organized crime are mainly different phenomena.release: gangs

the helsinki police are visibly present in the city and ready to operate around the clock every day of the year.preparing for the fight against terrorism has also improved the performance of the helsinki police for military threats.

preventing terrorism is key to addressing the polarization and inequality of society. polarization and marginalization increase the feeling of being outside, which is a breeding ground for violent radicalization and terrorism.

according to the state council's decision in principle, the focus of the fight is on prevention, which means addressing the background causes, triggers and other factors that can lead to violent radicalization and, in extreme cases, recruitment to terrorist groups.

the police have the main responsibility for combating terrorism. the ability to combat terrorism consists of 's intelligence ability, local police's ability to prevent activities and operational response, and 's ability to investigate crimes.

from the police's point of view, street gangs are one part of the crime scene, which lives and changes all the time. the kind of crime that needs to be monitored and addressed: many of the leaders of street gangs are currently serving varying sentences for their crimes.

although it is fair to state that most of the people identified by the police who join street gangs have an immigrant background, stating this is not an open invitation to an anti-immigrant debate, but rather an invitation to think about what is the cause?

street gangs are, however, a different phenomenon than crimes committed by minors against each other, which have also received a lot of publicity, such as robberies and subjugating violence. there have always been various youth groups, and in general the phenomenon is not new in itself.

one word rarely perfectly describes all aspects of the phenomena, but even if it is imperfect, an expression that describes it is needed so that there can be a discussion about the problem and, above all, how to solve it.

the investigation also includes taking, recording and necessary processing of various samples. often, the crime scene investigation is done by the police department's technical crime investigators who specialize in it.

investigating a crime often also requires a technical criminal investigation. this means searching for, recording and investigating evidence. for example, recording fingerprints is technical criminal investigation.

the police use boats to monitor water traffic in finland's sea and lake areas. boat patrols participate in handling police alarm tasks, for example in the archipelago, where it is faster to get to the mission site by boat than by car.

in a short time, the police has become finland's largest operator organization of unmanned aviation. drones are used by the police, for example, to photograph crime scenes and search for missing persons.
the police have separate field overalls for summer and winter. in addition, the police also have uniforms for everyday life and parties.
the crowd control police, or jouha, takes care of safety in large crowds such as demonstrations.

bicycle police officers supervise public order and it is easy for them to move among citizens in downtown areas. fillari bollards monitor traffic and especially light traffic. there are also electrically assisted bicycles in use in helsinki.
a typical working day for a police horse often includes patrolling the city or maintaining order at large public events. important qualities for a police horse are courage, calmness and health.
the police are where the citizens are. one of the most important tasks is meeting people and talking.

the police's national emergency unit karhu is a special force whose basic task is to support all police units throughout finland. karhu, the national emergency unit of the police, established in , turned in may.

of the traffic control authorities, the police certainly play the most central role in maintaining traffic safety. the police intervenes in behavior that violates traffic rules and, among other things, directs traffic in exceptional situations such as traffic accidents.
the police do preventive work among young people. for example, it strengthens young people's trust in the police.
the police do a large part of their fieldwork in cars. the patrols use cars to move from one task place to another, and branded cars play an important role in visible order and traffic control.

a group of communication professionals work in the police, whose job it is to communicate police matters to citizens. police communication is helpful when you need information about the police or, for example, an interviewee for the media. the helsinki police department also communicates on tiktok these days.

the police band represents the police through music and it performs concerts throughout finland. the helsinki police band has existed since and was founded to promote interaction between the police and citizens.
the police's duties also include monitoring public order and safety. for example, at large public events, the police are on site to secure the events.

the police use motorcycles for traffic control and convoys. motorcycle police can get from one place to another quickly and nimbly. police motorcycles can be seen in the street scene from early spring to late fall.

during midsummer, the police are on patrol in various parts of helsinki, both on land and at sea. the boat police supervises, among other things, the way boats are driven, the use of life jackets, the driving condition of people on the water and the condition of equipment.

five tips from the police for boaters:1. remember the life jacket!2. head for the water.3. check the area's speed limits and traffic rules . be considerate of other boaters and follow good seamanship.5. remember to enjoy moving at sea!

helsinki police wishes everyone a happy and safe midsummer. the police also supervises on land and at sea during midsummer. in this thread, you can follow midsummer's eve from the police's point of view.
find out about the prohibited and restricted areas for water traffic here:

hello water sports! has compiled the prohibited and restricted areas of water traffic on one page. check the restrictions before going out on the water. also remember to put on a life jacket and be safe in the water.

the light traffic lanes of mannerheimintie are normally in use, but during the parade there is a large crowd, which is good to note.

alternative routes are recommended for cyclists and other people using light means of transport along the beach route on both sides, and you can also go through tl without obstacles. baana has restrictions at kansalaistor.

it's always case-by-case whether the intoxicated person poses an immediate danger to himself. the danger is not assessed as immediate in terms of the weather, for example, if the temperature is on the positive side. the assessment is also influenced by whether the person is still capable of independent decision-making.

from the point of view of the police and the law, intervening in the activities of intoxicated persons or, for example, taking them to a survival position is not entirely one-sided. the police can take an intoxicated person with them if they pose an immediate danger to themselves or someone else.

first of all, thanks for alerting the authorities and waiting for the authorities with the intoxicated person. if you are not completely sure of another person's condition, you should always wait for help to come with someone who is intoxicated or, for example, injured. you did exactly the right thing in this case.

police communication is regulated the most by the pretrial investigation act. the police will publish the name, picture, identification marks or all of them only for a reason that is necessary for the preliminary investigation.in a rule of law, judgments are distributed by the court. criminal procedure:

pretrial investigation act: "a person's name or picture may only be made public if it is necessary to investigate a crime, to reach a suspect of a crime, to prevent a new crime or to prevent damage caused by a crime."

it is not possible to obtain additional evidence for the majority of bicycle thefts through investigative measures. for this reason, degrees are suspended. the investigation will be reopened if new evidence is obtained.

if your bicycle is stolen: file an electronic crime report immediately. accurately record all bike identification information in the criminal report. they are not requested afterwards.more information:
be prepared for theft:1. write down the frame number of the bicycle. the police can issue a search warrant using the bike's serial number.2. take good pictures of the bike.3. get a decent lock.
the police can only actively investigate some bike thefts. the seriousness of the crime affects the investigation. for example, in april , the police solved a gross electric bike theft: .

chain about bicycle thefts when the police receives a criminal complaint about bicycle theft, the frame number of the bicycle is recorded in the system. the frame number can be used to check whether, for example, a bicycle found in connection with a gig has been reported as stolen.

when the detects a suspicion of drunk driving, a criminal report is filed. you don't have to go further than your own office or police car to do paperwork, because the necessary systems are carried in the police car. in the picture, the constable prepares a report in field conditions.
clients who are taken to forensic medicine must provide a "walk sample" along this line in addition to a blood sample.

the rapid drug test gives an indication of whether the has reason to suspect a so-called drug ring. based on this quick test, one driver is suspected to have used e.g. amphetamine and cannabis for blood tests in the forensic emergency room.

if the suspects the driver of so-called traditional drunken driving, the matter can be verified and clarified to the end in the police car with the help of a precision breathalyzer. if there is a suspicion of the use of drugs or narcotics in traffic, the customer must go for blood tests.

the task of the police is to find out the crime and its perpetrator within the framework of the law. often the perpetrator is known very quickly.the identity may also be known, but the police need witnesses to the crime.the pretrial investigation act limits the publication of images to exceptional situations only.
the police cannot tell events or signs too precisely to get objective testimony from witnesses.

the publication of pictures is almost always related to the identification of the suspect and even then it must be necessary.the police are looking for impartial witnesses to the events for the trial. a red t-shirt can be a good sign for those who have been at the event.
esittkintaki says that "a person's name or picture may only be made public if it is necessary to solve a crime, to reach the suspect of a crime...).

alarm tasks decreased overall, but home alarms increased. the number of domestic violence cases increased last year in and has remained at this level during the corona period, because people have spent significantly more time at home than in the years before the epidemic.

the number of drug crimes decreased. crimes involving the use of narcotics decreased the most. at the same time, more serious drug crimes were recorded than the previous year. from the decrease shown in the statistics, it is not possible to draw the conclusion that the use of narcotics has decreased.

the number of criminal law offenses reported to the helsinki police decreased at the beginning of the year. the number of property crimes and assault crimes decreased, but the number of sexual crimes increased in januaryjune.

make sure the kids and pets have eaten, drunk and peed before you leave, so you can concentrate on driving. check that the children are wearing seat belts or are secured in the car seat or baby seat. take breaks when needed. /3

load the car carefully, as loose objects are dangerous if you have an accident or have to brake suddenly. pack and secure the heaviest luggage at the bottom of the luggage compartment and tie down any items in the back seat. leave the hat rack empty. /3

be patient and calm when you go to the midsummer celebration, and prepare for a longer journey than usual. it is unnecessary to overtake in a long queue of cars, because overtaking only increases the accordion effect in the queue. the time gained by overtaking is usually vanishingly small. /3

feed, drink and pee the kids and pets before leaving so you can focus on driving. fasten the children in their belts, car seat or car seat. attach pets with harnesses to car mounts, pet cage to car mounts. take breaks. /3

you should be careful when loading the car, because loose items are dangerous during hard braking or in the event of an accident. pack and fasten heavy items in the lowest trunk, tie down items in the back seat. leave the hat shelf empty. /3

: go to midsummer with a patient and relaxed mind and allow time for the journey. there is no point in passing in a unified queue, it only increases the accordion movement of the queue. the time gain for overtaking is usually on the borderline between little and non-existent. /3

the monitoring focuses, for example, on cases where the visibility of the crosswalk is limited, but the vehicle does not slow down or, if necessary, stop before the crosswalk.
the monitoring pays attention to cases where a vehicle or tram has stopped in front of a crosswalk and if the vehicle passes it without stopping.
the supervision deals with, for example, cases where the driver of the vehicle neglects to give unobstructed passage to a pedestrian who is already on the crosswalk or is preparing to cross it.

why wasn't the demonstration against the corona restrictions broken up? inspector jarmo heinonen of the helsinki police answers:

the organizers of the demonstration did not follow the orders of the police to make the demonstration safe. the preliminary investigation is aimed at the organizers of the demonstration. the criminal title is an assembly violation, for which the possible punishment is a fine.

stopping the demonstration would not have been a reasonable and effective measure, as the potential exposures had already occurred. according to the police, a significant part of the demonstrators arrived at the demonstration from outside helsinki using public transportation.
freedom of speech and freedom of assembly are basic rights that the police protect equally. now the crowd was dispersed by letting the demonstration proceed to the end.

the demonstrators who gathered in the center of helsinki on saturday did not follow the police's orders to make the demonstration safe. the begins a preliminary investigation into the possible guilt of the organizers in an assembly violation.

the demonstrations organized at the national square have ended. according to the police's view, the demonstrations did not go according to the assembly law in all respects. possible criminal liability issues are clarified after the fact by means of a preliminary investigation.
some of the kansalaistor demonstrations have ended and people are leaving the area.
the demonstrations continue at kansalaistor after the demonstrators split into smaller groups. the police give the organizers permission to hold speeches, but require them to keep their distance.
the police are currently negotiating with the organizers about the demonstrations. the police require that the demonstrators be divided into smaller groups and keep the necessary distances.

the police will not allow the demonstrations to continue until the event is restored to legal order. in practice, this means complying with the restrictions of the infectious diseases act in order to maintain public safety.

youth violence and gang involvement must be taken seriously and addressed now, while we can still avoid the situation escalating. we must combat violence and prevent the causes that lead to it. the streets must be safe for everyone.

today hs has published a comprehensive article about the crimes that have occurred among young people recently.the phenomenon is not new and i have already discussed the phenomenon before, e.g. with the helsinki police, youth work on foot, social work professionals, representatives of organizations. /7

this is a complex problem that needs to be solved on many levels. there are no simple solutions, but the police, the city, schools and families all play an important role. cooperation is underway. this should be taken seriously.
the common denominator in a large number of serious violent crimes is disadvantage and marginalization. adult and juvenile crime is also often caused by substance abuse and mental health problems.

however, the youth group investigating crimes by minors of the helsinki police has noticed in its work that violent situations are increasingly related to narcotics and robberies that occur in situations where they are sold. in addition, young people are increasingly carrying edged weapons.

the helsinki police have the same understanding of young people who cause concern as those working in youth work, and information is constantly shared. the police make a child protection report when an underage youth shows signs of committing crimes or when the police otherwise become concerned about the youth.

crime in helsinki is becoming international and the number of young people causing concern is increasing. narcotics and being prepared with sharp weapons are behind violent crimes by young people. professional drug crime is also growing and becoming international.

/6 when it comes to preventing pickpocketing, everyone's personal care is emphasized. wallets, cards and bank ids should always be kept out of sight. when shopping online, you should find out the reliability of the sites.

/6 in addition, finns own a lot of cottages. the cabins are completely empty for part of the year, which attracts burglars. valuable property at the cabin includes household appliances, outboard motors and tools.

/6 what makes finland an attractive place for criminal activity? the high standard of living and sparsely populated areas may be reasons. in many places, we are far from the prying eyes of our neighbors, after all, we are a country of long distances and sparsely populated in terms of population density.

/6 everyone experiences the moments after a burglary in their own way. however, it should be noted that your own home is a place of safety and peace. after a burglary, your home may feel unsafe and oppressive for a long time. in the worst case, there may be a move ahead.

/6 cross-border crime is e.g. in drug, economic and property crimes. typical cross-border property crimes in finland include, for example, apartment burglaries, pickpocketing and metal theft. in addition, fraud crime has been clearly on the rise in recent years.

/6 excerpts from the article of the cross-border crime investigation team in the helsinki crime investigation blog.cross-border crime has become more professional: crimes are planned, prepared and executed more carefully than before

according to the new legislation, cyclists must now also use a rear light. the bicycle must use a white or light yellow light in the front and a red light in the back. there can be several lights, and they can be attached either to the bike or to the cyclist.
the new road traffic law that came into force in the summer requires bicycles to have front and rear lights in the dark, at dusk or if visibility is reduced.
this week, the helsinki police will increase the visibility of cyclists. the aim of the monitoring is to remind road users of the importance of visibility in the dark.

the aim of the police's use of force was to break up the crowd obstructing traffic. the demonstration was allowed to continue in kaisaniemi park and on the sidewalk. (4/4)

considering the significant traffic inconvenience and the duration of the situation, the police resorted to the mildest possible use of force to break up the crowd. in this case, it was a gas spray. (3/4)

and a little off topic, but related to the theme: if you're buying a used bicycle, find out about the origin of the bike (e.g. ask to see the receipt) so you don't end up supporting criminal activity. the "law of supply and demand" applies here as well.

in this case, there is a higher probability that you will get your stolen bike back if it "comes against the police" in connection with another police mission or, for example, in connection with a larger confiscation of stolen bicycles.
if your bike is stolen, file a criminal complaint where you provide the best possible identification and identification information about your bike.

all reports made to the police always go through a certain process. in the case of bicycle thefts, this includes, among other things, that the identification information of the property is stored in the police system.

as stated, the helsinki police are investigating bike thefts. however, they are not a special focus or priority in the investigation, such as e.g. crimes against life and health or crimes against children.

according to the instructions, inappropriate users can be removed and the communication of a user who repeatedly breaks the rules can be blocked in the police profile. the author is not notified of the deletion and blocking of the message. /7
the basis for technical blocking is the police's rules of discussion on the police's social media sites: . /7

parliament's ombudsman: "it therefore affects to some extent the possibility to participate in the discussion on social issues on twitter. however, a possible blocking does not limit the access to information on an open twitter account." /7
parliament's ombudsman: "blocking a twitter account mainly affects the ability of the targeted person to comment or retweet the tweets of the channel in question." /7

the parliamentary ombudsman has confirmed in several complaint decisions that "freedom of speech does not include the unconditional and unlimited right to express one's opinions in a certain communication channel maintained by another". /7
